hint.title: Matching between your loop (in the source code) and the binary loop
hint.txt:
The binary loop is composed of 5 FP arithmetical operations:
  • 3: addition or subtraction
  • 2: multiply
The binary loop is loading 12 bytes. The binary loop is storing 16 bytes.

expert.title: Cycles and memory resources usage
expert.txt:
Assuming all data fit into the L1 cache, each iteration of the binary loop takes 2.38 cycles. At this rate:
  • 5% of peak load performance is reached (5.05 out of 96.00 bytes loaded per cycle (GB/s @ 1GHz))
  • 14% of peak store performance is reached (6.74 out of 48.00 bytes stored per cycle (GB/s @ 1GHz))

header: 6% of peak computational performance is used (2.11 out of 32.00 FLOP per cycle (GFLOPS @ 1GHz))

gain.workaround:
• Try to reorganize arrays of structures to structures of arrays
  • Consider to permute loops (see vectorization gain report)
gain.title: Code clean check
gain.txt:
Detected a slowdown caused by scalar integer instructions (typically used for address computation).
By removing them, you can lower the cost of an iteration from 2.38 to 1.50 cycles (1.58x speedup).

gain.workaround:
• Try another compiler or update/tune your current one
  • Remove inter-iterations dependences from your loop and make it unit-stride:
    • If your arrays have 2 or more dimensions, check whether elements are accessed contiguously and, otherwise, try to permute loops accordingly
    • If your loop streams arrays of structures (AoS), try to use structures of arrays instead (SoA)
gain.details:
All VPU instructions are used in scalar version (process only one data element in vector registers).
Since your execution units are vector units, only a vectorized loop can use their full power.
gain.title: Vectorization
gain.txt:
Your loop is not vectorized.
Only 33% of vector register length is used (average across all VPU instructions).
By vectorizing your loop, you can lower the cost of an iteration from 2.38 to 0.75 cycles (3.17x speedup).

potential.workaround:
Try to change order in which elements are evaluated (using parentheses) in arithmetic expressions containing both ADD/SUB and MUL operations to enable your compiler to generate FMA instructions wherever possible.
For instance a + b*c is a valid FMA (MUL then ADD).
However (a+b)* c cannot be translated into an FMA (ADD then MUL).
potential.title: FMA
potential.txt: Presence of both ADD/SUB and MUL operations.

header:
Warnings:
  • Non-innermost loop: analyzing only self part (ignoring child loops).
  • Ignoring paths for analysis
  • Too many paths. If you really need to analyze all of the 37 paths individually, rerun with max-paths=37
  • RecMII not computed since number of paths is unknown or > max_paths
  • Streams not analyzed since number of paths is unknown or > max_paths
Try to simplify control and/or increase the maximum number of paths per function/loop through the 'max-paths-nb' option. This loop has 37 execution paths. The presence of multiple execution paths is typically the main/first bottleneck. Try to simplify control inside loop: ideally, try to remove all conditional expressions, for example by (if applicable):
  • hoisting them (moving them outside the loop)
  • turning them into conditional moves, MIN or MAX
